p: In total, 72093 traps were effective and 944 rodents were trapped, with M. musculus (38.77%) and R. norvegicus (48.20%) being the predominant species. The number of captured R. flavipectus and other species gradually decreased over time. The number of M. musculus increased each year from 2006 to 2009; however, after the peak (n = 93) in 2009, the number decreased. The number of R. norvegicus captured decreased from 68 to 34 rodents per year during 2006 to 2010, but 35 rodents were captured in 2011, after which downwards trend continued over the study period ( Table 1). With respect to the rodent community composition per year (excluding 2006 and 2007), M. musculus and R. norvegicus comprised most of the trapped rodents ( Fig 4).
